name: Boeing 777-200ER
description: The Boeing 777-200ER (Extended Range) is the most popular variant of the original 777-200, with increased fuel capacity and higher maximum takeoff weight for extended range operations. First delivered in 1997, it can fly up to 7,065 nautical miles, enabling nonstop transpacific and transatlantic routes. The 777-200ER was the workhorse of many airlines' long-haul fleets before the 777-300ER entered service.

zones.name: Cockpit
zones.description: The 777-200ER flight deck is identical to the base 777-200, with fly-by-wire controls and six LCD displays.

zones.name: Forward Galley
zones.description: The forward galley for first and business class service on long-haul extended range routes.

zones.name: Forward Lavatory
zones.description: Forward lavatories near the premium class cabin. Extended range flights require higher usage rates.

zones.name: Forward Vestibule
zones.description: The forward entry vestibule at door 1L/1R for primary passenger boarding.

zones.name: Forward Cabin Left Seats
zones.description: Left window and middle seats in the forward cabin, configured for premium passengers on extended range routes. Many airlines offer lie-flat business class along the port side for long-haul comfort.

zones.name: Forward Cabin Left Aisle
zones.description: The left aisle of the forward cabin, one of the twin aisles in the wide-body 777 layout. Crew use this aisle for premium meal and beverage service on extended range flights.

zones.name: Forward Cabin Center Seats
zones.description: Center seats in the forward cabin between the twin aisles. On extended range configurations, this section typically features 2- or 3-abreast business class with direct aisle access.

zones.name: Forward Cabin Right Aisle
zones.description: The right aisle of the forward cabin, providing a second service path through the premium class section on long-haul flights.

zones.name: Forward Cabin Right Seats
zones.description: Right window and middle seats in the forward cabin, mirroring the left side premium class seating. Window seats feature views through the 777's large cabin windows on extended range routes.

zones.name: Mid Cabin Left Seats
zones.description: Left seat section in the mid cabin, typically 3-abreast premium economy or economy seating on extended range routes. Located over the wing and center fuel tank.

zones.name: Mid Cabin Left Aisle
zones.description: The left aisle of the mid cabin, running over the wing box where additional fuel capacity enables extended range operations.

zones.name: Mid Cabin Center Seats
zones.description: Center seats in the mid cabin between the twin aisles, configured as 3- or 4-abreast economy for extended range flights. Enhanced in-flight entertainment helps on long sectors.

zones.name: Mid Cabin Right Aisle
zones.description: The right aisle of the mid cabin, used by cabin crew for meal and beverage cart service on extended range flights lasting up to 14 hours.

zones.name: Mid Cabin Right Seats
zones.description: Right seat section in the mid cabin, with economy seating along the starboard side. Window seats offer views over the right wing and engine.

zones.name: Aft Cabin Left Seats
zones.description: Left seat section in the aft economy cabin. On extended range flights of 12+ hours, aft passengers benefit from proximity to the rear lavatories.

zones.name: Aft Cabin Left Aisle
zones.description: The left aisle of the aft cabin, connecting the mid cabin to the aft vestibule and rear service areas on long-haul routes.

zones.name: Aft Cabin Center Seats
zones.description: Center seats in the aft economy cabin between the twin aisles. Last rows may have limited recline. Extended range flights make comfort features more important.

zones.name: Aft Cabin Right Aisle
zones.description: The right aisle of the aft cabin, providing access to the rear doors and galley on extended range services.

zones.name: Aft Cabin Right Seats
zones.description: Right seat section in the aft economy cabin, mirroring the port side. Window seats offer aft views toward the horizontal stabilizer.

zones.name: Aft Vestibule
zones.description: The aft entry vestibule with rear boarding doors.

zones.name: Aft Galley
zones.description: The aft galley with extended provisions for long-haul flights requiring multiple meal services.

zones.name: Aft Lavatory
zones.description: Multiple aft lavatories serving the economy cabin on extended range missions.

zones.name: Forward Cargo Hold
zones.description: The forward lower-deck cargo hold beneath the forward cabin, accommodating LD3 containers side by side. Heated and pressurized for temperature-sensitive cargo on extended range routes.

zones.name: Aft Cargo Hold
zones.description: The aft lower-deck cargo hold beneath the mid and aft cabins, the largest cargo compartment on the aircraft. Handles containerized baggage and freight for extended range operations.

zones.name: Bulk Cargo Hold
zones.description: The bulk cargo compartment at the rear of the lower deck, used for loose-loaded baggage and small freight items on long-haul flights.

zones.name: Cargo Access
zones.description: The forward cargo access passage connecting the main deck to the lower cargo holds for ground loading operations.

zones.name: Nose
zones.description: The nose section with weather radar and forward avionics bay, identical to the 777-200.

zones.name: Forward Fuselage
zones.description: The forward lower fuselage with the forward cargo hold for LD3 containers.

zones.name: Mid Fuselage
zones.description: The center lower fuselage with wing box and additional fuel capacity in the center tank for extended range missions.

zones.name: Aft Fuselage
zones.description: The aft lower fuselage with the rear cargo hold.

zones.name: Tail
zones.description: The tail section with APU and empennage structures.

zones.name: Left Wing
zones.description: The port wing with increased fuel capacity for extended range operations. Additional structural reinforcement supports the higher maximum takeoff weight.

zones.name: Right Wing
zones.description: The starboard wing with matching fuel capacity and structural reinforcement for ER operations.

zones.name: Left Engine
zones.description: The left GE90-94B engine rated at 94,000 lbs thrust, same as the base 777-200. Some operators chose PW4090 or Trent 892 engines.

zones.name: Right Engine
zones.description: The right GE90-94B engine, identical to the left.

zones.name: Left Main Gear
zones.description: The left six-wheel bogie main gear, strengthened for the 777-200ER's higher maximum takeoff weight of 297,550 kg.

zones.name: Right Main Gear
zones.description: The right six-wheel bogie main gear, identical to the left unit.

zones.name: Nose Gear
zones.description: The steerable nose gear with dual wheels.

zones.name: Vertical Stabilizer
zones.description: The vertical stabilizer providing directional stability, identical to the base 777-200.

zones.name: Horizontal Stabilizer
zones.description: The trimmable horizontal stabilizer with elevators for pitch control.

zones.name: APU
zones.description: The Honeywell 331-500 APU in the tail cone for ground power and ETOPS dispatch requirements.

components.name: Captain's Control Column
components.description: The captain's fly-by-wire control column with yoke for pitch and roll commands.
components.interactionText: Grasp the captain's yoke. The fly-by-wire system converts inputs to electronic signals for the flight computers.

components.name: First Officer's Control Column
components.description: The first officer's fly-by-wire control column, electronically linked to the captain's controls.
components.interactionText: The first officer's yoke provides independent fly-by-wire control authority.

components.name: Throttle Quadrant
components.description: Twin thrust levers for the GE90-94B engines with autothrottle capability for long-haul fuel efficiency.
components.interactionText: The thrust levers control the GE90 engines. On ER missions, fuel management across wing and center tanks is critical.

components.name: Rudder Pedals
components.description: Fly-by-wire rudder pedals with speed-dependent authority limiting.
components.interactionText: Press pedals for yaw control. Authority automatically reduces at higher airspeeds.

components.name: Primary Flight Display (PFD)
components.description: Large-format PFD identical to the base 777-200.
components.interactionText: The PFD shows attitude, airspeed, altitude, heading, and all flight mode annunciations.

components.name: Navigation Display (ND)
components.description: Navigation display with extended range map modes essential for transoceanic ETOPS navigation.
components.interactionText: View the navigation display showing oceanic tracks, ETOPS diversion airports, and equal-time points.

components.name: Engine Indicating and Crew Alerting System
components.description: EICAS dual-screen display monitoring both GE90-94B engines and aircraft systems.
components.interactionText: Monitor engine parameters and fuel state across all tanks. Extended range operations require careful fuel monitoring.

components.name: Overhead Panel
components.description: Systems control panel with additional fuel management controls for extended range tank configuration.
components.interactionText: The overhead panel includes fuel crossfeed and center tank pump switches essential for ER fuel management.

components.name: Mode Control Panel (MCP)
components.description: Autopilot interface for managing the extended range flight profile.
components.interactionText: Set cruise altitude and speed for optimal fuel burn on long-haul routes. Step climbs are common as fuel burns off.

components.name: Flight Management Computer (FMC)
components.description: Triple-redundant FMC optimized for long-range routes with ETOPS capability and oceanic navigation.
components.interactionText: Program transoceanic routes with ETOPS alternate airports and equal-time points for extended overwater operations.

components.name: Forward Left Entry Door (1L)
components.description: The main wide-body boarding door with dual-lane evacuation slide.
components.interactionText: The wide-body entry door with powered door assist and armed evacuation slide.

components.name: Aft Left Entry Door (4L)
components.description: The aft left entry door for rear boarding and emergency evacuation.
components.interactionText: The aft door meets wide-body evacuation requirements for passenger loads up to 440.

components.name: Forward Galley Unit
components.description: Premium class galley with provisions for extended range meal services spanning multiple time zones.
components.interactionText: The forward galley stocks provisions for two or three meal services on extended range flights.

components.name: Aft Galley Unit
components.description: The aft economy galley with extended storage for long-haul catering requirements.
components.interactionText: Extended range flights require larger aft galley provisions for multiple meal and snack services.

components.name: Overhead Storage Bins
components.description: Wide-body overhead bins across three rows providing ample storage for long-haul passenger baggage.
components.interactionText: Three rows of overhead bins accommodate carry-on luggage for the full 9-10 abreast seating configuration.

components.name: Row 1 First Class Seats
components.description: First class seats typically configured as enclosed suites with lie-flat beds for ER long-haul routes.
components.interactionText: First class suites feature lie-flat beds, personal IFE screens, and premium amenities for flights exceeding 12 hours.

components.name: Forward Cabin Business Class Seats
components.description: Business class seats configured for long-haul comfort on extended range routes. The 777-200ER's forward cabin typically features lie-flat seats in a 2-3-2 or 1-2-1 configuration, designed for flights up to 14 hours.
components.interactionText: Sit in a business class seat designed for extended range flights. The seat converts to a fully flat bed for overnight routes. Find the personal entertainment system, noise-canceling headphone jack, and universal power outlet.

components.name: Mid Cabin Economy Seats
components.description: Economy seats in the mid cabin of the extended range 777-200ER. Configured in 3-3-3 layout for long-haul routes. Airlines often provide enhanced in-flight entertainment and more generous meal service on the extended range routes this variant flies.
components.interactionText: Sit in a mid cabin economy seat on this long-haul configured aircraft. The seatback screen offers hundreds of hours of entertainment for extended flights. Check the USB port, adjustable headrest with wings, and footrest.

components.name: Aft Cabin Economy Seats
components.description: Aft economy seats on the 777-200ER. On long-haul extended range routes, aft cabin passengers benefit from proximity to rear lavatories and galleys. The last few rows may have limited recline. The GE90 or Rolls-Royce Trent engines are audible from this section.
components.interactionText: Sit in an aft cabin seat on this extended range aircraft. The powerful engines are closer here. Check the seatback entertainment, overhead bin, and read the safety card in the seat pocket.

components.name: Forward Cabin Left Overhead Bins
components.description: Overhead storage bins above the left seats in the forward cabin. The 777's three-row bin system provides ample storage for premium class passengers on extended range flights.
components.interactionText: Open the left overhead bin above the forward cabin seats. Premium class bins accommodate larger bags needed for extended range travel.

components.name: Forward Cabin Right Overhead Bins
components.description: Overhead storage bins above the right seats in the forward cabin, mirroring the left side configuration.
components.interactionText: Open the right overhead bin in the forward cabin. Business class bins may have extra space due to lower passenger density in premium cabins.

components.name: Mid Cabin Left Overhead Bins
components.description: Overhead storage bins above the left seats in the mid cabin over the wing section.
components.interactionText: Open the left overhead bin in the mid cabin. These bins serve economy passengers on the port side of the aircraft.

components.name: Mid Cabin Right Overhead Bins
components.description: Overhead storage bins above the right seats in the mid cabin, mirroring the left side.
components.interactionText: Open the right overhead bin in the mid cabin. Starboard bins serve passengers on the right side of the aircraft.

components.name: Aft Cabin Left Overhead Bins
components.description: Overhead storage bins above the left seats in the aft economy cabin on extended range routes.
components.interactionText: Open the left overhead bin in the aft cabin. Bins in the rear section tend to have more space available during boarding.

components.name: Aft Cabin Right Overhead Bins
components.description: Overhead storage bins above the right seats in the aft economy cabin.
components.interactionText: Open the right overhead bin in the aft cabin. The last bins before the aft vestibule and galley area.

components.name: Forward Cabin Left Window
components.description: A cabin window on the left side of the forward cabin, offering views during the extended range journey across oceans and continents.
components.interactionText: Look through the forward cabin left window. On transoceanic extended range routes, you might see nothing but ocean for hours before landfall appears.

components.name: Forward Cabin Right Window
components.description: A cabin window on the right side of the forward cabin, providing views on extended range routes.
components.interactionText: Look through the forward cabin right window. The 777's larger windows let in more natural light on long daytime sectors spanning multiple time zones.

components.name: Mid Cabin Left Window
components.description: A cabin window on the left side of the mid cabin over the wing, with views of the engine and leading edge slats.
components.interactionText: Look through the mid cabin left window over the wing. The left GE90 engine nacelle is visible, along with slats and the wing fuel vents.

components.name: Mid Cabin Right Window
components.description: A cabin window on the right side of the mid cabin with views over the starboard wing on extended range flights.
components.interactionText: Look through the mid cabin right window. The right GE90 engine and spoiler panels are visible on the wing upper surface.

components.name: Aft Cabin Left Window
components.description: A cabin window on the left side of the aft cabin, with views of the wing trailing edge and the world below on long-haul routes.
components.interactionText: Look through the aft cabin left window. On extended range flights, watch the sunset or sunrise as you cross time zones over vast oceans.

components.name: Aft Cabin Right Window
components.description: A cabin window on the right side of the aft cabin with views toward the horizontal stabilizer on extended range journeys.
components.interactionText: Look through the aft cabin right window. The horizontal stabilizer is visible aft, and below, the terrain or ocean stretches to the horizon.

components.name: Forward Exit Row Seats
components.description: Exit row seats in the forward cabin with extra legroom near the overwing emergency exits. On extended range flights, the extra space is especially valued.
components.interactionText: Sit in the forward exit row seat. The extra legroom is welcome on extended range flights lasting up to 14 hours. Read the exit row safety briefing card.

components.name: Forward Cabin Window Seat
components.description: A window seat in the forward business class cabin offering panoramic views on extended range transoceanic routes.
components.interactionText: Sit in a forward cabin window seat. On extended range routes, watch the ocean pass below for hours before landfall. Adjust the window shade and settle in for the long flight.

components.name: Forward Cabin Center Seat
components.description: A center section seat in the forward business class cabin, positioned between the twin aisles with easy access to both sides on extended range flights.
components.interactionText: Sit in a forward cabin center seat. Business class center seats offer privacy partitions and direct aisle access from both sides, ideal for long-haul rest.

components.name: Mid Cabin Exit Row Seats
components.description: Exit row seats at the overwing emergency exits in the mid cabin, offering the most legroom in economy class on extended range flights.
components.interactionText: Sit in the overwing exit row with extra legroom. On a 14-hour extended range flight, the extra space makes a real difference. Review the exit row briefing card.

components.name: Mid Cabin Window Seat
components.description: A window seat in the mid cabin economy section over the wing, with views of the engine and flight control surfaces on extended range routes.
components.interactionText: Sit in a mid cabin window seat over the wing. Watch the GE90 engine and wing flex during turbulence on the long transoceanic crossing.

components.name: Mid Cabin Center Seat
components.description: A center section seat in the mid cabin economy class, with access to both aisles. The seatback entertainment system is essential on extended range flights.
components.interactionText: Sit in a center economy seat. While there is no window, the personal entertainment screen has hundreds of hours of content for the extended flight.

components.name: Aft Cabin Exit Row Seats
components.description: Exit row seats in the aft cabin near the rear emergency exits, with extra legroom valued on extended range routes.
components.interactionText: Sit in the aft exit row with extra legroom. Familiarize yourself with the exit operation procedure on the briefing card for this extended range aircraft.

components.name: Aft Cabin Window Seat
components.description: A window seat in the aft economy cabin on the extended range variant, with views of the wing trailing edge and the terrain or ocean far below.
components.interactionText: Sit in an aft cabin window seat. Looking out on this extended range flight, watch the wing trailing edge and flap track fairings as the world passes below.

components.name: Last Row Economy Seat
components.description: The very last row of economy seats on the extended range variant. Limited recline but closest to rear lavatories, which are heavily used on long-haul flights.
components.interactionText: Sit in the last row of economy. Limited recline, but you are steps from the lavatories and galley, useful on extended range flights lasting up to 14 hours.

components.name: Forward Cargo LD3 Containers
components.description: LD3 unit load devices in the forward cargo hold. The wide-body cross-section accommodates LD3 containers two abreast for efficient cargo operations on extended range routes.
components.interactionText: Examine the LD3 containers in the forward hold. Each aluminum container holds up to 1,588 kg and fits the curved lower fuselage contour of the wide-body 777.

components.name: Forward Cargo Restraint Net
components.description: The cargo restraint net system in the forward hold, securing LD3 containers during all phases of flight including turbulence on extended range routes.
components.interactionText: Inspect the cargo net restraint system. Heavy-duty nets with quick-release fittings secure containers against the 9g forward load requirement.

components.name: Forward Cargo Door
components.description: The powered forward cargo door on the right side of the fuselage, providing access to the forward lower-deck cargo hold.
components.interactionText: Examine the powered forward cargo door. Hydraulic actuators open the door upward, and a ball-mat system inside guides LD3 containers into position.

components.name: Aft Cargo LD3 Containers
components.description: LD3 containers in the aft cargo hold, the largest cargo compartment on the 777-200ER. Essential for carrying freight and baggage on extended range routes.
components.interactionText: Examine the LD3 containers in the aft hold. The largest compartment handles the majority of baggage and cargo for extended range operations.

components.name: Aft Cargo Restraint Net
components.description: The cargo restraint system in the aft hold, securing containers and pallets throughout the extended range flight.
components.interactionText: Inspect the aft cargo restraint nets securing cargo against forces up to 9g forward, 1.5g sideward, and 2g upward.

components.name: Aft Cargo Door
components.description: The powered aft cargo door on the right side of the fuselage behind the wing, providing access to the rear cargo hold.
components.interactionText: Examine the aft cargo door. It opens upward with hydraulic assistance and has a powered drive system for loading LD3 containers.

components.name: Bulk Cargo Loading Area
components.description: The bulk cargo compartment at the rear of the lower deck for loose-loaded baggage, mail, and small freight on extended range routes.
components.interactionText: Examine the bulk cargo area. Loose baggage and mail are hand-loaded through a small door, with a conveyor belt for irregularly shaped items.

components.name: Left GE90-94B Engine
components.description: The left GE90-94B engine rated at 94,000 lbs thrust, certified for 180-minute ETOPS operations.
components.interactionText: The GE90-94B is ETOPS certified, meaning the aircraft can fly up to 180 minutes from the nearest diversion airport on one engine.

components.name: Right GE90-94B Engine
components.description: The right GE90-94B engine, identical to the left. ETOPS certification requires proven engine reliability.
components.interactionText: Both GE90 engines must meet strict reliability standards for ETOPS extended overwater operations.

components.name: Nose Landing Gear Assembly
components.description: The nose gear with dual wheels, identical to the base 777-200.
components.interactionText: The nose gear steers the aircraft during taxi operations at airports worldwide.

components.name: Left Main Landing Gear
components.description: The left six-wheel bogie strengthened for the ER's higher 297,550 kg MTOW.
components.interactionText: The strengthened main gear supports the ER variant's higher maximum takeoff weight for extended range missions.

components.name: Right Main Landing Gear
components.description: The right six-wheel bogie, identical to the left.
components.interactionText: Six wheels per main gear distribute the aircraft's weight for global airport compatibility.

components.name: Left Aileron
components.description: The left fly-by-wire aileron on the port wing.
components.interactionText: The fly-by-wire aileron is controlled by Primary Flight Computers through hydraulic actuators.

components.name: Right Aileron
components.description: The right fly-by-wire aileron on the starboard wing.
components.interactionText: The right aileron works in opposition to the left for roll control.

components.name: Left Trailing Edge Flaps
components.description: Single-slotted Fowler flaps and flaperon on the left wing.
components.interactionText: The Fowler flaps extend rearward on tracks. Flaperons combine flap and aileron functions.

components.name: Right Trailing Edge Flaps
components.description: Single-slotted Fowler flaps and flaperon on the right wing.
components.interactionText: The right flaps deploy symmetrically with the left for balanced lift augmentation.

components.name: Left Leading Edge Slats
components.description: Full-span leading edge slats on the left wing.
components.interactionText: Full-span slats delay stall to higher angles of attack for safe low-speed operations.

components.name: Right Leading Edge Slats
components.description: Full-span leading edge slats on the right wing.
components.interactionText: Symmetric slat deployment maintains balanced lift during configuration changes.

components.name: Elevator
components.description: Fly-by-wire elevators with pitch envelope protection.
components.interactionText: The fly-by-wire elevator provides pitch control with automatic envelope protection.

components.name: Rudder
components.description: Fly-by-wire rudder with triple-redundant hydraulic actuators and speed-dependent limiting.
components.interactionText: The rudder has three hydraulic actuators for redundancy on extended overwater operations.

components.name: Wing Spoilers / Speed Brakes
components.description: Fly-by-wire spoiler panels for speed brakes, ground spoilers, and roll augmentation.
components.interactionText: Spoilers deploy symmetrically for drag or differentially for roll control.

components.name: Weather Radar Antenna
components.description: Long-range weather radar essential for detecting weather on transoceanic routes where diversion options are limited.
components.interactionText: Extended range weather detection is critical for oceanic operations where route deviations must be carefully planned.

components.name: APU Exhaust
components.description: The Honeywell 331-500 APU required for ETOPS dispatch as an in-flight backup power source.
components.interactionText: The APU must be operable for ETOPS dispatch, providing backup electrical power and bleed air if an engine fails over water.

controlSurfaces.name: Ailerons
controlSurfaces.movementDescription: Yoke turned: fly-by-wire computers command aileron deflection modulated by airspeed.
controlSurfaces.flightEffect: Differential lift rolls the aircraft with envelope protection preventing excessive bank angles.

controlSurfaces.name: Elevator
controlSurfaces.movementDescription: Yoke pulled back: elevators up. Pushed forward: elevators down. Fly-by-wire provides pitch rate control.
controlSurfaces.flightEffect: Elevator commands pitch rate changes with envelope protection against stall and overspeed.

controlSurfaces.name: Rudder
controlSurfaces.movementDescription: Left pedal: rudder left. Right pedal: rudder right. Speed-dependent authority limiting.
controlSurfaces.flightEffect: Rudder yaws the aircraft for coordinated turns and crosswind operations. Critical for single-engine ETOPS scenarios.

controlSurfaces.name: Trailing Edge Flaps
controlSurfaces.movementDescription: Flap lever positions: UP, 1, 5, 15, 20, 25, 30. Fowler flaps extend on tracks.
controlSurfaces.flightEffect: Flaps increase lift and drag for the 777-200ER's higher weight takeoff and landing operations.

controlSurfaces.name: Leading Edge Slats
controlSurfaces.movementDescription: Slats deploy automatically with flap selection for maximum lift augmentation.
controlSurfaces.flightEffect: Slats delay stall for safe approach speeds at the ER's higher landing weights.

controlSurfaces.name: Spoilers / Speed Brakes
controlSurfaces.movementDescription: Speedbrake lever: symmetric deployment. Roll input: asymmetric deployment.
controlSurfaces.flightEffect: Speed brakes manage descent rate. Ground spoilers deploy on landing for maximum braking.

controlSurfaces.name: Flaperons
controlSurfaces.movementDescription: Flaperons droop with flap extension and deflect differentially for roll.
controlSurfaces.flightEffect: Combined flap and aileron function for high-lift and roll control.
